body_html: In Python3, if an integer is within the range of int32 or int64 (depending on how you compiled the Python binary), it is the same as int in Python2. Once it exceeds the range of machine-native integers, it will be automatically converted to what is equal to long in Python2. The process is completely transparent, thus it is safe to just use int(numImages) in Python3.
body_text: In Python3, if an integer is within the range of int32 or int64 (depending on how you compiled the Python binary), it is the same as int in Python2. Once it exceeds the range of machine-native integers, it will be automatically converted to what is equal to long in Python2. The process is completely transparent, thus it is safe to just use int(numImages) in Python3.
body: In Python3, if an integer is within the range of int32 or int64 (depending on how you compiled the Python binary), it is the same as `int` in Python2. Once it exceeds the range of machine-native integers, it will be automatically converted to what is equal to `long` in Python2. The process is completely transparent, thus it is safe to just use `int(numImages)` in Python3.
